facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 204 of 1970 filed under Section 123 of the J. K. Representation of the People Act, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 204 of 1970. Appeal under Section 123 of the J. K. Representation of the People Act, 1957 from the judgment and order dated December 15, 1969 of the Jammu and Kashmir High Court in Election Petition No. 37 of 1967.

facts.text: Appeal against judgment and order dated December 15, 1969 of Jammu and Kashmir High Court in Election Petition No. 37 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 204 of 1970. Appeal under Section 123 of the J. K. Representation of the People Act, 1957 from the judgment and order dated December 15, 1969 of the Jammu and Kashmir High Court in Election Petition No. 37 of 1967. K. Garg, D. P. Singh, A. K. Gupta, R. K. Jain, V. J. Francis and S. P. Singh, for the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant and respondent filed nominations for election to Jammu Kashmir Legislative Assembly from Reasi Assembly Constituency in General Election 1967.

anchor.surface_text: In the General Election held in 1967, the appellant and the respondent had duly filed their numberinations for election to the Jammu Kashmir Legislative Assembly from the Reasi Assembly Constituency. Scrutiny of the numberination papers was companyducted on January 23, 1967 and the polling took place on February 21, 1967.

facts.text: Scrutiny of nomination papers conducted on January 23, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Scrutiny of the numberination papers was companyducted on January 23, 1967 and the polling took place on February 21, 1967. The companynting of the ballot papers took place on February 27, 1967 and the appellant was declared duly elected by a majority of 418 votes.

facts.text: Polling took place on February 21, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Scrutiny of the numberination papers was companyducted on January 23, 1967 and the polling took place on February 21, 1967. The companynting of the ballot papers took place on February 27, 1967 and the appellant was declared duly elected by a majority of 418 votes.

facts.text: Counting of ballot papers on February 27, 1967; appellant declared elected by majority of 418 votes.

anchor.surface_text: The companynting of the ballot papers took place on February 27, 1967 and the appellant was declared duly elected by a majority of 418 votes. The respondent filed an election petition on April 8, 1967 being No. 37 of 1967 challenging the election of the appellant on the ground that various companyrupt practices, set out in the petition, had been companymitted by the appellant, his agents and other persons with his companysent in the said election.

facts.text: Respondent filed Election Petition No. 37 of 1967 on April 8, 1967 challenging appellant's election on grounds of corrupt practices.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed an election petition on April 8, 1967 being No. 37 of 1967 challenging the election of the appellant on the ground that various companyrupt practices, set out in the petition, had been companymitted by the appellant, his agents and other persons with his companysent in the said election. In companysequence the respondent prayed for declaring the election of the appellant from the said companystituency as null and void.

facts.text: High Court declared appellant's election void based on corrupt practices in paragraphs 16, 17 and 20 of booklet Ex. P.W.1/II under Section 132(4) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The election of the appellant had been declared to be void by the High Court only on the ground that the matters mentioned in paragraphs 16, 17 and 20 of the booklet Ex. P. W. 1/II companystitute companyrupt practices under Section 132  4  of the Act companyresponding to Section 123  4  of the Representation of the People Act, 1951.

facts.text: Booklet Ex. P.W.1/II titled 'open letter from Dehati (Rural) Conference to Mr. Rishi Kumar Kaushal and other Jan Sangh leaders' published by Lal Singh (RW 53), active Congress worker and polling agent of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-item  a  of item No. 2 refers to the publication of a booklet under the caption open letter from Dehati  Rural  Conference to Mr. Rishi Kumar Kaushal and other Jan Sangh leaders. This is Ex. P. W. 1/ II. It was published by one Lal Singh R. W. 53, an active worker of the Indian National Congress and the agent of the appellant.

facts.text: Lal Singh published Ex. P.W.1/II in first week of December 1966 as reply to poster Ex. P.W.1/B by Jan Sangh.

anchor.surface_text: W. 53 Lal Singh has given evidence that he published the open letter Ex. P. W. 1 II as a reply to the poster Ex. P. W. 1/ B issued by the Jan Sangh. He has also stated that the companytents of Ex. P. W. 1 II are companyrect and that the publication was made in the first week of December, 1966.

facts.text: Booklet Ex. P.W.1/II distributed amongst voters from 1-2-1967 to 20-2-1967 by respondent's agents including election agent and appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Issue No. 2 runs as follows Whether the respondent, his election agent and agents published the booklet Dehati Conference kee Taraf se Shri Rishikumar Kaushal aur deegar Jansanghi leaderon ke nam Khuli Chitthi in the name of one Lal Singh an active worker of the Congress and distributed it amongst the voters of the Constituency from 1-2-67 to 20-2-1967

facts.text: High Court found overwhelming evidence of distribution of Ex. P.W.1/II by RW53, Congress workers, election agent and appellant during election.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court further finds that there is overwhelming evidence on record to show that the said booklet was distributed and circulated by the author of the booklet R. W. 53 and other workers of the Congress party including the election agent of the appellant and the appellant himself amongst the people in different villages of the Constituency during the election and also just before, the poll.

facts.text: Incident in September 1966: Dhani Ram and Baldev Singh (rural persons) went to Reasi, caught shopkeeper sawing wood unauthorizedly, attacked by urban people including respondent, kept in jail overnight.

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph 16- Who raised the question of the village and the town ? When in the month of September, 1966, two persons of the rural area Sailanjan--Dhani Ram and Baldev Singh came to Riasi, and they caught a shop keeper sawing wood in an unauthorised manner and you with the aid of your urban companyleagues made an attack on them and raised the question that these people from the village companye to town and drink and roam aimlessly like vagabonds etc and they were kept in jail for a night,

facts.text: Criminal complaint filed against respondent and others by Dhani Ram and Baldev Singh on September 19, 1966 before ADM Udhampur; compromised next day.

anchor.surface_text: Baldev Singh has given evidence as R. W. 37. He has deposed that about two years prior to his giving, evidence. he and Dhani Ram had gone to the town of Riasi and visited the shop of Shyam Lal Jargar.When a piece of timber was sought to be used as fire wood by Shyam Lal, Dhani Ram tried to seize the piece of timber on the ground that it belonged to the firm of jodha Mal and Company,

facts.text: Supreme Court held statements in paras 16,17,20 of Ex.PW1/II do not constitute corrupt practice under Sec 132(4); reversed High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, it follows that the finding of the High Court that the statements companytained in paragraphs 16, 17 and 20 amount to companyrupt practice under Section 132 4  of the Act, cannot be sustained.

facts.text: Supreme Court found evidence proves truth of allegations in para 16 regarding criminal complaint and compromise.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that the evidence referred to above is acceptable and it substantially proves the truth of the allegations regarding the incident referred to in paragraph 16 leading to the filing of the criminal companyplaints and their number being proceeded with due to companypromise arrived at between the parties.

facts.text: Respondent was sitting member of Legislative Assembly at material time.

anchor.surface_text: Rishi Kumar is the respondent herein and he was at the material time a sitting member of the Legislative Assembly.

facts.text: Lal Singh (RW53) deposed contents of Ex.PW1/II are correct.

anchor.surface_text: W. 53 Lal Singh has given evidence that he published the open letter Ex. P. W. 1 II as a reply to the poster Ex. P. W. 1/ B issued by the Jan Sangh. He has also stated that the companytents of Ex. P. W. 1 II are companyrect and that the publication was made in the first week of December, 1966.

facts.text: Dehati Conference set up on November 20, 1966 (para 20 of booklet).

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph 20. Now we have set up the Dehati Conference on November 20, 1966. Now you do what you please. Now numbervillager will companye to you for being hurt, number shall anyone else.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is companysequenay I allowed.

facts.text: High Court held allegations in paras 7,18,19 true, not corrupt practice.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court companysidered paragraphs 7, 18 and 19 together- and has held that the evidence establishes that the respondent was responsible for organisings demonstrations and instigating assaults on ministers and other Government Officers.

facts.text: Respondent belonged to Jan Sangh party.

anchor.surface_text: There is numbercontroversy that the respondent belonged to Jan Sangh Party.

facts.text: Criminal complaints filed by Baldev Singh (RW37) and Dhani Ram on Sep 20, 1966 before ADM Udhampur, forwarded to SHO Reasi.

anchor.surface_text: He has referred to the fact that he signed the companyplaint petitions and filed them in the Court of the A. D. Udhampur on September 20. 1966. The Magistrate forwarded the two companyplaints to the Station House Officer, Riasi, for investigation.

facts.text: Durga Dutt (RW18), lawyer and maternal uncle of appellant, filed complaints; produced vakalats Ex RW18/2 and RW18/2A.

anchor.surface_text: He has produced the vakalats Ex. W 18/2 and Ex. R. W. 18/2A, executed by Dhani Ram and Baldev Singh respectively in respect of the criminal companyplaint,

facts.text: Case compromised; respondent promised to pay any fine.

anchor.surface_text: W. 43 Amar Nath has spoken to his knowing Baldev Singh and Dhani Ram and also to the incident which took place in Riasi and their being beaten by the people including the respon- dent. He has further referred to R.W. 12 requesting him to accompany Baldev Singh and Dhani Ram to Udhampur for filing a criminal companyplaint and to his having actually accompanied them.

issues.text: Whether the matters mentioned in paragraphs 16, 17 and 20 of the booklet Ex. P. W. 1/II constitute corrupt practices under Section 132(4) of the J&K Representation of the People Act, 1957?

anchor.surface_text: the matters mentioned in paragraphs 16, 17 and 20 of the booklet Ex. P. W. 1/II constitute corrupt practices under Section 132  4  of the Act corresponding to Section 123  4

issues.text: Whether the statements in paragraphs 16, 17 and 20 of Ex. P. W. 1/II are statements of fact in relation to the personal character or conduct of the respondent?

anchor.surface_text: we will now proceed to consider whether the statements in paragraph 16, 17 and 20 in Ex. P. W. 1/ II are statements in relation to the personal character or conduct of the respondent.

issues.text: Whether the allegation in paragraph 16 that the respondent apologized and extricated himself from a criminal case by paying money to the other side is true?

anchor.surface_text: This leads us with the question whether the High Court is correct in its finding that in paragraph 16, the respondent is described as one who apologized for extricating himself from a criminal case by paying money to the other side.

holdings.text: The statements contained in paragraphs 16, 17 and 20 of Ex. P.W.1/II do not amount to corrupt practice under Section 132(4) of the J&K Representation of the People Act, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, it follows that the finding of the High Court that the statements contained in paragraphs 16, 17 and 20 amount to corrupt practice under Section 132 4  of the Act, cannot be sustained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statements do not relate to personal character/conduct or are substantially true; High Court misinterpreted text and evidence.

holdings.text: There are no statements of fact in paragraphs 17 and 20 of Ex. P.W.1/II in relation to the personal character or conduct of the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: To conclude there are no statements of fact in paragraphs 17 and 20 of Ex. R. W. 1/ II in relation to the personal character or conduct of the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis shows criticism of political neglect and town-village disparity, not personal depravity; precedents distinguish personal from public/political.

holdings.text: The allegation in paragraph 16 regarding the respondent extricating himself from a criminal case by apology and compromise is substantially true.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that the evidence referred to above is acceptable and it substantially proves the truth of the allegations regarding the incident referred to in paragraph 16 leading to the filing of the criminal complaints and their not being proceeded with due to compromise arrived at between the parties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence of witnesses RW37, RW18, RW43, documents prove incident, filing of complaints, compromise.

holdings.text: Publication of false statement as counterblast to opponent's propaganda does not preclude it from being a corrupt practice under Section 132(4).

anchor.surface_text: As stated by this Court in T. K. Gangi Reddy , and others 1 , case Section 123 4  defining corrupt practice, is not conditioned by any proviso to the effect that it would cease to be a corrupt practice if the statement was made to counteract the rival statement of an opponent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent in T.K. Gangi Reddy holds s.123(4) not conditioned by proviso; irrelevant if counterblast.

holdings.text: Respondent in appeal can support High Court judgment on grounds negatived by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: In Ramanbhai Ashabhai Patel v. Dabhi Ajitkumar Fulsinji and others 1  it has been held by this Court that On a consideration of justice, this Court should permit the respondent to support the judgment in his favour even upon the grounds which were negatived in that judgment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent in Ramanbhai permits supporting decree on rejected grounds for justice.

holdings.text: Statements in paragraphs 7, 18 and 19 of Ex. P.W.1/II do not constitute corrupt practice under Section 132(4) as they are true.

anchor.surface_text: All these circumstances, in our opinion, do establish that the respondent must have either instigated or had been a party to the violent demonstration referred to in paragraphs 7, 18 and 19 and it cannot be said that the allegations contained therein are false.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence including RW50, RW28, RW31 proves respondent instigated/participated in violent demonstrations; true statements not corrupt practice.

holdings.text: Statements in paragraphs 8 and 10 of Ex. P.W.1/II do not relate to personal character or conduct of respondent.

anchor.surface_text: the statements contained in paragraph 10, quoted above, has no reference to the personal character or conduct of the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Criticize political actions (agitations, wheat supply); precedents hold public/political open to criticism even if false.

holdings.text: The appeal is allowed and the judgment of the High Court is set aside.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is consequently allowed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No corrupt practices proved; reverses High Court on paras 16,17,20.

holdings.text: It is unnecessary to decide publication and distribution of the booklet as no corrupt practice found.

anchor.surface_text: On the above conclusion arrived at by us it becomes unnecessary to consider the second contention of Mr. Garg that the High Courts finding regarding the publication and distribution of the booklet Ex. P. W. 1 /11, is erroneous and is not based upon the evidence in the case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Obiter; moot as ingredients of s.132(4) not satisfied.

precedents.citation: T. K. Gangi Reddy v. M. C. Anjaneya Reddy and others 1

anchor.surface_text: In T. K. Gangi Reddy v. M. C. Anjaneya Reddy and others 1  this Court stated that the words Personal character and companyduct are so clear that they do number require further elucidation or definition. The character of a person may ordinarily be equated with his mental or moral nature. Conduct companynotes a persons actions or behaviour. It has been further held that if otherwise a statement companyes under sub-section  4  of Section 123 as companyrupt practice, it will be numberanswer to plead that the statement was made as a companynter blast to a rival statement of an opponent.

precedents.case_name: T. K. Gangi Reddy v. M. C. Anjaneya Reddy
precedents.cited_proposition: words 'Personal character and conduct' are clear and do not require elucidation; counter-blast is no defence to corrupt practice under Section 123(4)
precedents.cited_holding: The character of a person may ordinarily be equated with his mental or moral nature. Conduct connotes a persons actions or behaviour.

anchor.surface_text: In dealing with sub-section  4  of Section 123 in Inder Lal vLal Singh  2  this Court observed as follows It would be numbericed that in prescribing the requirement that the false statement should have relation to the personal character of the candidate, a distinction is intended to be drawn between the personal character of the, candidate and his public or political character Dissemination of false statements about the personal character of the candidate thus companystitute a companyrupt practice.

precedents.cited_proposition: Distinction between personal character and public or political character of candidate
precedents.cited_holding: Dissemination of false statements about the personal character of the candidate constitutes corrupt practice.

anchor.surface_text: It has further been pointed out in Kultar Singh v. Mukhtiar Singh  3  that the document must be read as a whole and its purport and effect determined in a fair, objective and reasonable manner and that at the election time the atmosphere is usually surcharged with partisan feelings and emotions and soma allowance must be made in that regard.

precedents.cited_proposition: Document to be read as whole in fair manner with allowance for election atmosphere

anchor.surface_text: Dealng with sub-section  4  of Section 123, in Sheopat Singh Ram Pratap  1  this Court observed as follows The sub-section is designed to achieve this dual purpose, namely, freedom of speech and prevention of malicious attack on personal character or companyduct etc. of rivals.

precedents.cited_proposition: Purpose of Section 123(4): freedom of speech but prevent malicious false statements on personal character; bona fide false statements protected if not believed false; must be calculated to prejudice
precedents.cited_holding: The word calculated means designed; emphasis on calculated effect.

precedents.citation: Dev Kanta Barooah v. Golok Chandra Baruah and others 2

anchor.surface_text: In Dev Kanta Barooah v. Golok Chandra Baruah and others  2 this Court had to companysider whether an allegation calling as Deshdrohita a person who was having military companytracts during the 1942 movements was a statement in relation to his personal character or companyduct.

precedents.case_name: Dev Kanta Barooah v. Golok Chandra Baruah
precedents.cited_proposition: Allegation of 'Deshdrohita' relates to political conduct, not personal character
precedents.cited_holding: No imputation of depravity or immorality.

precedents.citation: Guruji Shrihar Baliram Jivatode v. Vithalrao and others 1

anchor.surface_text: In Guruji Shrihar Baliram Jivatode v. Vithalrao and others 1  it was held by this Court that the statements which were Linder companysideration do number make any reflection on the moral or mental qualities of the person against whom those statements had been made.

precedents.case_name: Guruji Shrihar Baliram Jivatode v. Vithalrao
precedents.cited_proposition: Statements not reflecting moral or mental qualities not relating to personal character

anchor.surface_text: The following observation of Darling J. in Cumberland  Cockermouth Divisional   1  case has been quoted with approval in some of the decisions of this Court referred to above What the Act forbids is this. You shell number make or publish any false statement of fact in relation to the personal character or companyduct of such candidate if you do, it is an illegal practice.

precedents.cited_proposition: Distinction between false statement of fact re personal character/conduct vs political position/reputation/action
precedents.cited_holding: Act prohibits false statements relating to personal character and conduct, not political.

precedents.citation: Ramanbhai Ashabhai Patel v. Dabhi Ajitkumar Fulsinji and ,others 1

anchor.surface_text: In Ramanbhai Ashabhai Patel v. Dabhi Ajitkumar Fulsinji and ,others  1  it has been held by this Court that On a companysideration of justice, this Court should permit the respondent to Support the judgment in his favour even upon the grounds which were, negatived in that judgment.

precedents.case_name: Ramanbhai Ashabhai Patel v. Dabhi Ajitkumar Fulsinji
precedents.cited_proposition: Respondent can support decree on grounds negatived below

precedents.citation: Shri Thepfulo Nakhro Angami v. Shrimati Raveluei alias Rani M. Shaiza 2

anchor.surface_text: The same view has been reiterated recently by this Court in Shri Thepfulo Nakhro Angami v. Shrimati Raveluei alias Rani M. Shaiza  2 . Though the above decisions were given under the Representation of the People Act, 1951, Mr. Grag, learned companynsel for the appellant, accepted the position that the same principles are applicable to the present appeal which has been filed under the Act.

precedents.case_name: Shri Thepfulo Nakhro Angami v. Shrimati Raveluei alias Rani M. Shaiza
precedents.cited_proposition: Same principle as above: respondent can support on negatived grounds

precedents.citation: T. K. Gangi Redd , and others 1

anchor.surface_text: As stated by this Court in T. K. Gangi Redd , and others  1 , case Section 123  4  defining companyrupt practice, is number companyditioned by any proviso to the effect that it would cease to be a companyrupt practice if the statement was made to companynteract the rival statement of an opponent.

precedents.case_name: T. K. Gangi Reddy v. M. C. Anjaneya Reddy
precedents.cited_proposition: Section 123(4) not conditioned by counter-blast proviso

precedents.citation: T. K. Gangi Reddy v. M. C. Anjaneya Reddy and others 1

anchor.surface_text: In this companynection the companynsel relied on the decision of this Court in T. K. Gangi Reddy v. M. C. Anjaneya Reddy and others 1  wherein it has been held that a statement which attributes acts of violence, for example, instigation of murder, throwing of stones at public meetings etc. even though such acts are done during his political career is a statement relating to the personal character and companyduct of the candidate.

precedents.case_name: T. K. Gangi Reddy v. M. C. Anjaneya Reddy
precedents.cited_proposition: Attributing acts of violence to candidate relates to personal character even if during political career

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, it follows that the finding of the High Court that the statements contained in paragraphs 16, 17 and 20 amount to corrupt practice under Section 132 4  of the Act, cannot be sustained.
The appeal is companysequenay I allowed.
To conclude there are no statements of fact in paragraphs 17 and 20 of Ex. R. W. 1/ II in relation to the personal character or conduct of the respondent.
The appeal is companysequenay I allowed.

anchor.surface_text: As stated by this Court in T. K. Gangi Reddy , and others 1 , case Section 123 4  defining corrupt practice, is not conditioned by any proviso to the effect that it would cease to be a corrupt practice if the statement was made to counteract the rival statement of an opponent.
The appeal is companysequenay I allowed.
